0.0_en:
Uefa has fined the Football Association and the Football Association of Ireland after the national anthems were booed before the Republic of Ireland played England in the Nations League in September.

European football's governing body imposed a £10,500 fine (12,500 euros) on the Football Association (FA) following England fans' booing of Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium.

The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) received a fine of £8,400 (10,000 euros) after home supporters booed God Save The King.

The FA's punishment is greater because the England fans' booing was deemed a repeat offence.

Uefa imposed further punishment on the FAI, with a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the lighting of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a pitch invasion by a spectator.

The FA was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a supporter coming on to the field of play.

England won the September 7 match 2-0 with goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
0.1_en:
UEFA has imposed penalties on the Football Association and the Football Association of Ireland following the national anthems being disrespected before the Republic of Ireland's match against England in the Nations League in September.

UEFA has fined the Football Association £10,500 (12,500 euros) for England fans' repeated disrespect of the national anthem, Amhran na bhFiann, during the match at Aviva Stadium. 

The Football Association of Ireland was fined £8,400 (10,000 euros) after their home supporters disrespected God Save The King. 

The FA received a higher fine due to the repeated nature of the England fans' disrespect. 

UEFA has further penalized the FAI, with a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the lighting of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a spectator's pitch invasion. 

The FA was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a supporter's unauthorized entry onto the field. 

England secured a 2-0 win in the September 7 match, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
0.2_en:
Following the Republic of Ireland's match against England in the Nations League in September, UEFA has taken disciplinary action against both the Football Association and the Football Association of Ireland due to the disrespect shown towards their national anthems.

The Football Association has been fined £10,500 (12,500 euros) for England fans' repeated disregard of the Republic of Ireland's national anthem, Amhran na bhFiann, during the match at Aviva Stadium, while the Football Association of Ireland was fined £8,400 (10,000 euros) for their home supporters disrespecting God Save The King.

The Football Association received a higher fine due to the repeated nature of the disrespect shown by England fans. 

Additionally, the Football Association of Ireland was penalized with a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the lighting of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a spectator's unauthorized entry onto the field.

The Football Association was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a supporter's unauthorized entry onto the field. 

England secured a 2-0 win in the September 7 match, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

The Football Association was fined £10,500 (12,500 euros) due to England fans' persistent disrespect towards the Republic of Ireland's anthem, while the Football Association of Ireland received a £8,400 (10,000 euros) fine for their supporters' disrespect of "God Save The King."

The higher fine for the Football Association was due to the recurring disrespect shown by England fans.

England emerged victorious in the September 7 encounter with a 2-0 scoreline, courtesy of goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

The English FA incurred a £10,500 fine for disrespecting "Amhran na bhFiann," the national anthem of the Republic of Ireland, while the FAI of the Republic of Ireland faced more severe penalties amounting to £35,750. These penalties consisted of £13,200 for inadequate recognition of "God Save The Queen," the British national anthem, £8,400 for fan misconduct, £5,000 for unauthorized access to the field, and an additional £9,150 (£5,000 for using flares and £4,150 for unauthorized access to the field). Notably, both the English FA and the FAI of the Republic of Ireland were penalized for unauthorized access to the field. The Republic of Ireland suffered a 0-2 defeat to England on September 7, with Jack Grealish and Declan Rice scoring the winning goals.

1.0_en:
Deonte Mowatt-Slater was found with a suspected stab wound after he crashed on Courtauld Road, on the corner of Beachcroft Way

A murder investigation has been opened after a 16-year-old boy was found fatally injured in north London. Deonte Mowatt-Slater died after his motorbike hit a lamppost following a suspected stabbing. Met Police officers were called in the early hours of Tuesday to reports of a crash on Courtauld Road in Islington. Medics at the scene said he was found to have a suspected knife injury, and despite attempts to save his life, he died.

There have been no arrests and inquiries are ongoing. A number of crime scene cordons are in place in the area, including in Courtauld Road where is it believed an altercation took place before the crash, and in Sussex Road. A Met spokesperson said officers were "working hard to establish the sequence of events that led to this tragic loss of a young life".
1.1_en:
In north London, a fatal incident occurred where 16-year-old Deonte Mowatt-Slater was discovered with severe injuries. The incident took place at the intersection of Courtauld Road and Beachcroft Way. According to reports, Mowatt-Slater was riding his motorbike when he collided with a lamppost, and it was suspected that he had been stabbed prior to the crash. Emergency services were summoned to the scene in the early hours of Tuesday, and despite their efforts to revive him, Mowatt-Slater succumbed to his injuries.

The Met Police have initiated a murder investigation following this tragic event. No arrests have been made, and investigations are ongoing. The scene of the collision on Courtauld Road and an adjacent road, Sussex Road, have been cordoned off for further examination. Witnesses or anyone with information regarding the altercation that may have preceded the crash are urged to contact the police. The Met Police spokesperson stated that they are diligently working to piece together the events that led to the unfortunate loss of life.
1.2_en:
In the north London area, a tragic incident occurred where 16-year-old Deonte Mowatt-Slater was found severely injured at the intersection of Courtauld Road and Beachcroft Way. Reports suggest that Mowatt-Slater was riding his motorbike when he collided with a lamppost. It is suspected that he had been stabbed before the crash. Emergency services were called to the scene in the early hours of Tuesday, but despite their attempts to save him, Mowatt-Slater passed away due to his injuries.

The Met Police have launched a murder investigation following this unfortunate event. No arrests have been made, and investigations are currently underway. The scene of the collision on Courtauld Road and the adjacent road, Sussex Road, have been sealed off for further investigation. Witnesses or anyone with information regarding any altercation that might have happened before the crash is requested to contact the police. The Met Police spokesperson emphasized that they are working diligently to gather all the facts surrounding the incident that led to the loss of life.

According to the accounts, Mowatt-Slater was riding his motorbike when he collided with a lamppost. Preliminary investigations indicate that he may have been stabbed prior to the crash. The authorities were alerted to the incident in the early hours of Tuesday, yet unfortunately, despite their best efforts, Mowatt-Slater succumbed to his injuries and passed away.

The Metropolitan Police have initiated a murder investigation following this sad occurrence. No suspects have been apprehended, and investigations are ongoing. The site of the crash on Courtauld Road and the adjoining road, Sussex Road, have been cordoned off for a more comprehensive examination. The police are urging witnesses or anyone with knowledge of any confrontation that could have transpired prior to the accident to come forward with information. The Met Police spokesperson underscored their commitment to meticulously uncovering every detail regarding the incident that resulted in the fatal outcome.

The authorities were notified of the incident on a Tuesday morning, and although medical responders attended promptly, they were unable to save Mowatt-Slater due to the severity of his injuries.

Following this tragic event, the Metropolitan Police have launched a murder investigation into Mowatt-Slater's death. Although no suspects have been identified at this stage, the investigation is ongoing. To gain a more detailed understanding of the scene, the police have set up a crime scene cordon that includes Courtauld Road and Sussex Road. The public is being asked to come forward with any information they may have regarding a potential dispute that may have led to the incident. The Metropolitan Police are committed to conducting a comprehensive and meticulous investigation into the circumstances surrounding Mowatt-Slater's death.

Preliminary reports suggested that Mowatt-Slater had crashed into a lamppost. However, a meticulous investigation carried out by the Metropolitan Police revealed potential evidence of a stabbing prior to the accident. This discovery raises the possibility that Mowatt-Slater may have had a previous injury, which could have aggravated his condition and led to his death.

Despite immediate medical attention, Mowatt-Slater's injuries proved fatal. In response to this tragic event, the Metropolitan Police have initiated a murder investigation and are vigorously exploring various leads. Currently, no arrests have been made. To obtain more information regarding the circumstances preceding the incident, the Metropolitan Police have closed off Courtauld Road and Sussex Road as a crime scene and are soliciting public assistance for any information regarding disputes or altercations that may have taken place prior to the incident. The Metropolitan Police remain committed to a thorough investigation, leaving no stone unturned in their pursuit of understanding the exact sequence of events that resulted in Mowatt-Slater's untimely demise.

This discovery suggests that Mowatt-Slater may have suffered a prior injury, which could have exacerbated his condition and ultimately led to his death.

The Metropolitan Police remain resolute in their commitment to a thorough investigation, leaving no aspect unexamined in their pursuit of understanding the sequence of events that led to Mowatt-Slater's untimely passing.

2.0_en:
The prosecution case against former Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson on historical sex offence charges is progressing “on track”, a review hearing in Newry has heard.

The court has set 3 July for a preliminary enquiry, the next stage in the case.

Sir Jeffrey, 61, is charged with 11 offences – one count of rape; one of gross indecency involving a child; and nine of indecent assault.

His wife, Lady Eleanor Donaldson, 58, a co-accused, faces four aiding and abetting charges.

The offences are alleged to have occurred between 1985 and 2006 and involve two alleged victims.

Neither of the accused appeared during a three minute hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.

The court was told case papers were received by their solicitors on Tuesday, allowing the preliminary inquiry to go ahead as planned in July.

Both the accused are required to attend court on 3 July.

The Donaldsons were arrested at their home on 28 March and charged by police after a day of questioning.

Sir Jeffrey resigned as DUP leader after being charged.

In a letter to the party he said he would be strenuously contesting the charges.
2.1_en:
A review hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court has been informed that the prosecution's case against Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, the former leader of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), is proceeding as scheduled in relation to historical sex offence charges. 

A preliminary enquiry, the next step in the case, has been set for July 3rd. Sir Jeffrey, 61, faces 11 charges, including one count of rape, one of gross indecency involving a child, and nine of indecent assault. 

His wife, Lady Eleanor Donaldson, 58, who is also a co-accused, is charged with four aiding and abetting offences. The alleged offences took place between 1985 and 2006 and involve two alleged victims.

During a brief hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, neither of the accused was present. However, it was stated that the case papers had been received by their solicitors the previous day, allowing the preliminary inquiry to proceed as planned in July.

Both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor are required to attend court on July 3rd. The couple was arrested at their home on March 28th and charged by police following a day of questioning. 

Following the charges, Sir Jeffrey stepped down as DUP leader, stating in a letter to the party that he would vigorously contest the allegations.

Sir Jeffrey is charged with one count of rape, one of gross indecency involving a minor, and nine counts of indecent assault. Lady Eleanor is accused of aiding and abetting in four offenses. The alleged incidents are claimed to have taken place between 1985 and 2006 and involve two accusers.

Neither defendant was present at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, but it was confirmed that their legal representatives had received the case files the previous day. As a result, the preliminary inquiry, scheduled for July 3rd, could proceed as planned.

Both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor are expected to appear in court on July 3rd. They were taken into custody at their residence on March 28th and charged by the police following an extensive day of questioning.

After the charges were made public, Sir Jeffrey resigned as DUP leader, asserting in a letter to the party that he would strongly contest the allegations.

Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor Donaldson, previous heads of the DUP, are presently on trial due to historical claims of sexual misconduct that emerged on July 3rd. The accusations encompass a timeframe from 1985 to 2006 and implicate two distinct individuals with numerous allegations.

Sir Jeffrey, aged 61, is confronting ten charges, which include rape, gross indecency with a minor, and indecent assault. Lady Eleanor, 58, is implicated in facilitating four of these incidents. Initially, Sir Jeffrey's planned court appearance on July 3rd was missed, but his legal team instigated the preliminary inquiry the day prior, leading to both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor appearing in court on that date. They were formally charged and remanded in custody on March 28th, following an extensive probe.

Subsequent to the accusations, Sir Jeffrey relinquished his position as DUP leader, transmitting a letter expressing his intent to challenge the levied charges against him.

Former leaders of the DUP, Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor Donaldson, are currently on trial after allegations of historical sexual misconduct surfaced on July 3rd. The claims span a period from 1985 to 2006 and involve two people with numerous accusations against them. 

Sir Jeffrey, who is 61 years old, faces ten charges, including rape, gross indecency with a minor, and indecent assault. Lady Eleanor, 58, is accused of being involved in facilitating four of these incidents. Initially, Sir Jeffrey was scheduled to appear in court on July 3rd, but his legal team initiated the preliminary hearing a day earlier, leading to both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor appearing in court on that date. They were formally charged and remanded in custody on March 28th, following a thorough investigation.

After the allegations surfaced, Sir Jeffrey stepped down as DUP leader, submitting a letter stating his intention to contest the charges against him.

3.0_en:
France manager Didier Deschamps says his decision to leave captain Kylian Mbappe out of the squad for this month's Nations League double-header is a "one-off".

The Real Madrid forward was not selected for upcoming matches against Israel and Italy.

Mbappe, 25, was left out of France's squad in October for two Nations League matches as a precaution given he had just returned from injury and had been expected to return for selection this month.

"I've had discussions with him, it is a decision that I took for this block of matches only," Deschamps said at a news conference on Thursday. "Kylian wanted to come."

The forward, who joined Real Madrid on a free transfer last summer from Paris St-Germain, has struggled for form since moving to the Bernabeu.

Mbappe has scored eight goals in 15 appearances for the La Liga club but has only netted once in his past five games.

Real, who won both the Champions League and La Liga last season, were beaten 4-0 by rivals Barcelona last month and trail the Catalans by nine points in the league.

Mbappe, a World Cup winner in 2018, has scored 48 goals in 86 appearances for France.
3.1_en:
France manager Didier Deschamps clarifies that leaving captain Kylian Mbappe out of the squad for the Nations League matches against Israel and Italy is a singular decision. 

Mbappe, 25, had previously been omitted from France's squad in October as a precaution after returning from injury. Although he was expected to return for selection this month, Deschamps made a call that only applies to the upcoming matches, and Mbappe had even expressed a desire to be included.

This decision comes as Mbappe continues to struggle for form since joining Real Madrid from Paris St-Germain on a free transfer last summer. In 15 appearances for the La Liga club, Mbappe has scored eight goals, but his recent form has been particularly poor, netting just once in his last five games. 

Real Madrid, who achieved a historic double by winning the Champions League and La Liga last season, suffered a 4-0 loss to Barcelona last month and currently trail their rivals by nine points in the league. 

Mbappe, a World Cup winner in 2018, has a notable record with France, having scored 48 goals in 86 appearances.

4.0_en:
The success of the ITV drama 'Mr Bates vs The Post Office' means the key plot points of this scandal are now well known. But the thorough nature of an inquiry like this ensures it can still shock.

Take a four-minute exchange at just after 11 this morning. The campaigner Lord Arbuthnot recalled a meeting where he was, once again, told by the Post Office there were no issues with the Horizon IT system.

Jason Beer KC then listed various bugs and acquittals and cancelled investigations and asked if the former MP had been told about them at that meeting. Time after time the response came: "no".

Another word has been repeated a lot today: "Robust". It was the way Post Office officials described that bug-ridden system.

The man in charge of a short-lived mediation scheme - retired judge Sir Anthony Hooper - said that, looking back, there was never a chance of resolution so long as Post Office bosses 'robustly' maintained there was nothing wrong with Horizon.

Tomorrow, we start hearing from those former Post Office bosses. The stage has been set for the next act of this, still shocking, drama.
4.1_en:
The ITV drama 'Mr Bates vs The Post Office' has been a success, making the key plot points of this scandal widely known. However, the comprehensive nature of this inquiry ensures that it can still have a profound impact, evoking shock.

A pivotal exchange occurred approximately four minutes after 11 am this morning. Lord Arbuthnot, a campaigner, recalled a meeting where he was once again told by Post Office officials that there were no issues with the Horizon IT system.

Jason Beer KC then presented a series of bugs, acquittals, and cancelled investigations, inquiring if the former MP had been informed about them during the meeting. The consistent response was a negative one: "no".

The term "robust" has been frequently used today, describing how Post Office officials portrayed the flawed Horizon system.

Sir Anthony Hooper, the former head of a short-lived mediation scheme, stated that, in retrospect, there was little chance of resolving the issue as long as Post Office executives maintained their stance that the system was functioning properly.

Tomorrow, we will begin hearing from those former Post Office executives, setting the stage for the next chapter in this ongoing and still-shocking drama.

Sir Anthony Hooper, the previous head of a brief mediation initiative, expressed that, in hindsight, it was unlikely to resolve the predicament while Post Office executives persisted in their belief that the system was operating effectively.

5.0_en:
Road closed after serious crash on bridge

Police advised motorists to find alternative routes after they closed the A4019

Police closed a busy Gloucestershire road following a crash on a bridge over the M5. Gloucestershire Police said officers were called to reports of the crash involving two cars at about 10:45 BST on Saturday on the A4019 Tewkesbury Road in Cheltenham. The force said the "serious" crash happened on the bridge at junction 10 of the M5 and people inside the cars were being treated by paramedics. The road closure was in place for several hours on the A4019 between Cheltenham and Coombe Hill. It reopened just before 15:00 BST.

This follows another crash on the A433 Tetbury Road in Cirencester, involving two vehicles. Anyone who witnessed the incident has been asked to contact the force.
5.1_en: A major road in Gloucestershire was shut down for several hours following a serious car accident on a bridge over the M5. The incident occurred at approximately 10:45 BST on Saturday on the A4019 Tewkesbury Road in Cheltenham, where two cars collided at the bridge near junction 10. Gloucestershire Police responded to the scene and paramedics were treating the people involved in the crash. As a result, the police advised drivers to take alternative routes, and the road closure between Cheltenham and Coombe Hill was in effect until it reopened just before 15:00 BST. This accident occurred shortly after another two-vehicle crash on the A433 Tetbury Road in Cirencester, and anyone who witnessed either incident is being asked to contact the police.

This incident took place around 10:45 BST on a Saturday, with two cars colliding near junction 10. The Gloucestershire Police were dispatched to the scene, and paramedics were attending to the individuals involved in the crash. As a consequence, the police urged drivers to utilize alternate routes, and the road blockage between Cheltenham and Coombe Hill persisted until it was lifted prior to 15:00 BST. This crash transpired soon after another two-vehicle collision on the A433 Tetbury Road in Cirencester. Anyone who observed either occurrence is requested to contact the police.

6.0_en:
Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

7.0_en:
A drug driver led police on an "exceptionally dangerous" high-speed pursuit through a town for 30 minutes.

Dashcam footage showed the 22-year-old driving on the wrong side of the road, the wrong way around a roundabout and head-on towards other vehicles in Northampton.

The pursuit, in the early hours of 9 November 2023, began after officers spotted a grey Audi A4 going through a red light in Wellingborough Road, and ended when it was stung in Overstone Gate.

A quantity of Class A drugs was found inside and the driver was later jailed for 30 weeks at Northampton Crown Court after admitting offences including driving without due care and attention, drug driving and failing to stop.

Det Con Mae Taylor said: "He drove exceptionally dangerously, whilst under the influence, and it is through sheer luck that he didn’t kill or seriously injure anyone."

A succession of alarming incidents unfolded when the driver disregarded a red light at Wellingborough Road, triggering a high-speed pursuit that terminated at Overstone Gate. Following an extensive probe, the authorities unearthed a substantial quantity of Class A drugs hidden within the vehicle.

Subsequently, the driver was apprehended and indicted for grave offenses, including reckless driving, driving under the influence, and disregarding traffic signals. At Northampton Crown Court, the motorist was sentenced to 12 weeks in prison for their perilous and reckless driving antics.

Detective Constable Mae Taylor was left astounded and dismayed, expressing her amazement, "It's astonishing that no fatalities or serious injuries resulted from this driver's flagrant disregard for safety and flagrant violation of traffic regulations."

8.0_en:
Ian Hislop opened Have I Got News For You on Friday by talking about an incident in which the rear window of the taxi he was in was smashed.

The editor of the satirical magazine Private Eye said: "I always say at this point I'm glad to be here, but this week I really mean it".

On Wednesday it was reported that a shot was fired at the taxi Hislop was in, but a police investigation found no evidence of a firearm being discharged and said a mechanical fault with the vehicle forced the window to shatter.

Neither Mr Hislop nor the driver, who reported the matter to the Met, was injured in the incident on Dean Street in Soho on Tuesday morning.

This video has been removed for rights reasons.

9.0_en:
The child was hit by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire

A man has been arrested after a child was airlifted to hospital with life-changing injuries following a hit-and-run. The youngster was hit by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire, at about 17:30 BST on Wednesday. The child, whose age has not been released, was airlifted to Liverpool's Alder Hey Hospital and is in a critical condition. Police confirmed on Thursday morning that a man suspected to be the rider of the motorbike has been arrested and in police custody.

Three people have also been arrested on suspicion of perverting the course of justice. North Wales Police Ch Insp Trystan Bevan said officers were trying to "locate a suspect who failed to stop following the collision".
9.1_en: A child, who is presently in critical condition, was struck by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire, around 17:30 BST on Wednesday. The incident resulted in the child being airlifted to Liverpool's Alder Hey Hospital. The suspected rider of the motorbike, whose age and identity have not been disclosed, has been taken into police custody after being apprehended. Additionally, three individuals have been detained on suspicion of obstructing justice in relation to this hit-and-run incident. North Wales Police Ch Insp Trystan Bevan stated that authorities are actively seeking to apprehend the suspect who fled the scene following the collision.

North Wales Police Chief Inspector Trystan Bevan reported that the authorities are currently working to locate the suspect who left the scene following the collision.

10.0_en:
Aerial footage shows police chasing a suspect on an LA highway, moments later the stolen truck is taken over by flames.

Officers from California Highway Patrol tried to stop the driver, who had fled with the vehicle at a gas station in Bakersfield, by deploying a set of spike strips.

The suspect didn't slow down and sparks were seen coming from the vehicle's front wheels. He carried on driving until coming to a stop when almost the entire cab started glowing.

The owner had been filling the tank when someone hopped into the cabin and drove away.

The suspect crossed the San Fernando Valley through a mostly empty highway and tried to run away by foot, but was arrested shortly after.
10.1_en:
Aerial footage captures a dramatic scene of police in pursuit of a suspect on a Los Angeles highway, only to see the stolen truck engulfed in flames moments later.

California Highway Patrol officers attempted to apprehend the driver, who had fled with the vehicle from a gas station in Bakersfield, by laying down spike strips to deflate the tires.

Despite the officers' efforts, the suspect refused to slow down, and sparks were visible emanating from the front wheels of the vehicle. The chase continued until the cab of the truck became fully engulfed in flames, forcing the suspect to come to a stop.

The stolen truck's owner had been filling the gas tank when the suspect jumped into the cabin and drove away.

After crossing the San Fernando Valley on a largely deserted highway, the suspect attempted to flee on foot, but was apprehended shortly thereafter.
10.2_en:
Aerial footage captured a high-speed police pursuit on a Los Angeles highway, where officers from the California Highway Patrol were in hot pursuit of a suspect who had stolen a truck from a gas station in Bakersfield.

The officers attempted to stop the vehicle by laying down spike strips to deflate the tires, but the suspect refused to slow down. As a result, sparks were visible coming from the front wheels, indicating that the tires were being severely damaged.

The chase continued until the cab of the truck became fully engulfed in flames, forcing the suspect to bring the vehicle to a halt. 

The suspect had stolen the truck after jumping into the cabin while the owner was filling the gas tank. The pursuit took the suspect across the San Fernando Valley on a largely deserted highway, where he attempted to flee on foot but was eventually apprehended shortly after.
10.3_en:
Aerial footage captured a high-speed police pursuit on a Los Angeles highway, where California Highway Patrol officers were in close pursuit of a suspect who had stolen a truck from a gas station in Bakersfield by jumping into the cabin while the owner was refueling.

The officers attempted to bring the vehicle to a stop by laying down spike strips to deflate the tires, but the suspect continued to drive at high speed. As a result, sparks were visible coming from the front wheels, indicating that the tires were severely damaged.

The chase continued until the cab of the truck became fully engulfed in flames, prompting the suspect to bring the vehicle to a halt.

The suspect had stolen the truck after jumping into the cabin while the owner was filling up the gas tank. The pursuit took the suspect across the San Fernando Valley on a largely deserted highway, where he attempted to escape on foot but was eventually apprehended shortly after.
10.4_en:
Aerial footage captured a high-speed police chase unfolding on a Los Angeles highway, where California Highway Patrol officers were hot on the heels of a suspect who had stolen a truck from a gas station in Bakersfield by sneaking into the cabin while the owner was pumping gas.

The officers attempted to halt the vehicle by deploying spike strips to deflate the tires, but the suspect continued to drive at breakneck speeds, resulting in sparks visible from the front wheels, indicating that the tires had suffered severe damage.

The pursuit continued until the cab of the truck became fully engulfed in flames, prompting the suspect to bring the vehicle to a stop.

The truck had been stolen after the suspect jumped into the cabin while the owner was refueling at the gas station. The chase took the suspect across the San Fernando Valley on a largely deserted highway, where he attempted to evade capture on foot but was eventually apprehended shortly after.
10.5_en:
Footage from above showed a thrilling police chase on a Los Angeles freeway, as California Highway Patrol agents pursued a thief who had stolen a truck from a Bakersfield gas station. The suspect had managed to enter the cab while the owner was filling up, unnoticed.

The law enforcement officers tried to stop the vehicle by laying down spike strips, but the thief persisted in driving at dangerously high speeds. The friction from the road caused visible sparks from the truck's front wheels, suggesting that the tires had been severely deflated.

The chase came to an end when the cab of the stolen truck burst into flames, forcing the suspect to pull over.

The incident began at a gas station in Bakersfield, where the thief had stolen the truck while the owner was refueling. The chase traversed the San Fernando Valley along an almost empty highway, with the suspect attempting to elude capture on foot before being apprehended shortly thereafter.
10.6_en:
A high-speed police pursuit unfolded on a Los Angeles freeway, as California Highway Patrol agents gave chase to a thief who had stolen a truck from a Bakersfield gas station. The suspect had slipped unnoticed into the cab while the owner was pumping gas.

Law enforcement officers attempted to bring the vehicle to a halt by deploying spike strips, but the thief continued driving at extremely hazardous speeds. The friction from the road caused sparks to fly from the truck's front wheels, indicating that the tires had suffered severe damage.

The pursuit came to a stop when the cab of the stolen truck erupted into flames, prompting the suspect to pull over.

The incident began at a gas station in Bakersfield, where the thief had stolen the truck while the owner was filling up. The chase then traversed the San Fernando Valley along a nearly deserted highway, with the suspect attempting to evade capture on foot before being apprehended shortly after.
10.7_en:
A high-speed police chase erupted on a Los Angeles freeway as California Highway Patrol agents pursued a suspect who had stolen a truck from a Bakersfield gas station. The thief had covertly entered the truck's cab while its owner was refueling at the pump.

Law enforcement officers attempted to stop the vehicle by laying down spike strips, but the suspect continued driving at perilously high speeds. The friction from the road caused sparks to fly from the truck's front wheels, indicating that the tires had suffered severe damage.

The pursuit came to a halt when the cab of the stolen truck burst into flames, prompting the suspect to pull over.

The incident started at a Bakersfield gas station where the suspect had stolen the truck while the owner was filling up the vehicle. The chase then traversed the San Fernando Valley along a nearly deserted highway, with the suspect attempting to evade capture on foot before being apprehended shortly after.

11.0_en:
A lorry driver has been fined after his load of slabs fell off his vehicle on a bend, writing off a passing car worth £50,000.

Neil and Alison Collins escaped with minor injuries, despite extensive damage to their Tesla's windscreen, bonnet and roof during the incident, which happened in Weston Longville near Norwich on 26 April.

Appearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the lorry driver pleaded guilty to using a motor vehicle where the weight, position or distribution of its load involved a danger of injury to any person.

He was ordered to pay a fine of £267, a victim surcharge of £34 and £85 in costs as well as receiving three points on his driving licence.
11.1_en:
A truck driver has been penalized after cargo from his vehicle slipped off at a turn, causing a £50,000 car, driven by Neil and Alison Collins, to be totaled. The incident occurred on April 26, in Weston Longville, close to Norwich.

The occupants of the Tesla, Neil and Alison Collins, sustained only minor injuries, but their car suffered significant damage to the windscreen, bonnet, and roof.

At Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver admitted to operating a motor vehicle with a load whose weight, placement, or distribution posed a risk to the safety of any individual.

The court imposed a fine of £267, a victim levy of £34, and £85 in expenses, in addition to adding three penalty points to his driving record.
11.2_en:
A truck driver has been held accountable for an accident that occurred on April 26 in Weston Longville, near Norwich, after his cargo shifted at a turn, resulting in a £50,000 car driven by Neil and Alison Collins being rendered completely unusable. Fortunately, the occupants of the Tesla, Neil and Alison Collins, escaped with minor injuries, despite the vehicle sustaining substantial damage to its windscreen, bonnet, and roof.

During a hearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver acknowledged that he was operating a vehicle with a load whose weight, positioning, or distribution presented a risk to the safety of others on the road.

As a result, the court issued a fine of £267, a victim compensation payment of £34, and £85 in court expenses, and also added three penalty points to his driving record.

At a hearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver admitted to operating a vehicle with a load whose weight, positioning, or distribution posed a risk to the safety of other road users. Consequently, the court imposed a fine of £267, a victim compensation payment of £34, and £85 in court expenses, and also added three penalty points to the driver's record.

During a hearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver accepted responsibility for operating a vehicle with a load that posed a risk to other road users due to its weight, positioning, or distribution. As a result, the court imposed a fine of £267, ordered the driver to pay £34 in victim compensation and £85 in court expenses, and also added three penalty points to their driving record.

The accident occurred when the cargo of a nearby truck shifted during a turn, causing extensive damage to the windscreen, bonnet, and roof of the Tesla. The vehicle was left unusable.

At a hearing in Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver admitted to driving a vehicle with a load that presented a danger to other road users due to its weight, positioning, or distribution. Consequently, the court imposed a fine of £267, mandated the driver to pay £34 in victim compensation and £85 in court expenses, and added three penalty points to their driving record.

11.7_en:
On April 26, a collision occurred near Norwich, Weston Longville, involving Neil and Alison Collins, who were driving a £50,000 Tesla. The accident caused minor injuries to the couple and severe damage to their vehicle, with the truck's cargo shifting during a turn, damaging the Tesla's windscreen, bonnet, and roof, leaving it unusable.

At a hearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver admitted to transporting a hazardous load due to excessive weight, improper positioning, or uneven distribution, posing a risk to other road users. Consequently, the court imposed a £267 fine, ordered the driver to pay £34 in compensation to the victims and £85 in court costs, and added three penalty points to their driving record.

At a hearing held at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver acknowledged transporting a hazardous load due to weight exceeding the limit, incorrect positioning, or uneven distribution. This action put other road users at risk. 12.0_en:
BBC correspondent Sean Dilley has been getting to know his new guide dog, also called Shawn. The pair have been learning to live together - walking, taking public transport, drinking coffee and even playing the guitar.

Sean, who was born with congenital blindness, has used guide dogs for nearly 25 years.

His previous dog, Sammy, retired after eight years. Sean had to wait 16 months before his new guide dog arrived, during which he used a white cane.

"Spending time with Shawn is the best feeling in the world," says Sean. "He is my independence and I have got my life back."
12.1_en:

Sean, who was born blind, has relied on guide dogs for approximately 25 years. His previous companion, Sammy, retired after eight years of dedicated service. Sean endured a 16-month wait for his new guide dog's arrival, during which he resorted to using a white cane.

Sean expresses, "The time I spend with Shawn is an indescribable sensation. He represents my freedom, and I have regained my life."

13.0_en:
A powerful earthquake has struck Japan, causing large waves and damage to buildings.

The 7.6-magnitude quake took place in Noto province on Honshu island, with officials urging people in coastal areas to move to higher ground.

Although the full extent of the damage is still unknown, dozens of buildings have collapsed in several towns, trapping a number of people under the rubble.

Thousands of people are spending the night in evacuation centres, as the Japanese military have been handing out food, water and blankets to those forced to leave their homes.

A major tsunami warning was issued, but was later downgraded to a warning, and then an "advisory".

The quake occurred in Noto province on Honshu island, prompting officials to instruct residents in coastal regions to relocate to higher ground for their safety.

Although the full extent of the damage remains unclear, multiple towns have seen numerous buildings collapse, leaving several individuals buried under the debris.

Thousands of people are currently taking refuge in evacuation centers, as the Japanese military distributes essential supplies such as food, water, and blankets to those displaced from their homes.

A major tsunami alert was initially issued, but it was later revised to a warning, and subsequently downgraded to an advisory.

The aftermath was marked by extensive devastation, with numerous buildings crumbling and leaving behind a scene of utter destruction. The risk of further collapses and the threat of massive waves posed a significant threat to nearby communities, jeopardizing their safety and security.

To mitigate these risks, local authorities swiftly ordered the evacuation of coastal residents who were at risk of being affected by the disaster. Several towns suffered severe damage to their infrastructure, and tragically, some residents were found trapped beneath the rubble.

Following the earthquake, thousands of people fled to evacuation centers to escape the chaos. The Japanese military played a crucial role by providing essential supplies, including food, water, and blankets, to help alleviate the difficulties faced by those affected.

An initial tsunami warning was issued, but it was later downgraded to a warning and eventually to an advisory, as the danger diminished and the likelihood of a major disaster decreased.

A massive 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck Honshu, Japan's largest island, causing widespread devastation, especially in the Noto region where numerous buildings and infrastructure were on the brink of collapse, and the danger of destructive ocean waves hung over the area.

In response to the disaster, local authorities swiftly activated evacuation procedures, relocating residents from high-risk coastal areas to safer zones. Several communities were severely impacted, with many people trapped beneath the rubble.

As the destruction worsened, thousands of people sought refuge in evacuation centers to escape the disaster. The Japanese military played a crucial role in providing critical assistance, distributing vital supplies such as food, water, and blankets to those affected by the earthquake.

Following the earthquake, an initial tsunami warning was issued, but it was later downgraded to a warning and eventually to an advisory as the tsunami threat diminished and the likelihood of a major disaster decreased.

Post-earthquake, an initial tsunami alert was broadcasted, but it was subsequently downgraded to a warning and eventually to an advisory as the tsunami risk subsided, and the prospect of a major disaster lessened.

14.0_en:
The boat was overcrowded, with more clambering on

On the north coast of France

The French police had struggled to stop the migrants as they’d charged from the dark sand dunes towards the sea. Several young men turned round to face the police, brandishing long sticks, and throwing flares or firecrackers. Two women with a child, who could not keep up with the group, were stopped by the police on the shoreline. One said she was from Iraq and was desperate to join her family in the UK. Once the migrants had boarded the inflatable boat they’d been dragging across the sand, the police made no further attempt to stop them. At one point the overloaded boat appeared to be beached on a sand bar by the retreating tide, but then it moved further out to sea. We waited as the light grew stronger and could see that several small rescue boats had been launched from a large French maritime rescue ship off the coast. The rescue boats seemed to circle the now distant inflatable boat for a time. It was only hours later that we learnt that there were dead onboard the inflatable.
14.1_en:
The inflatable boat was severely overcrowded as more people continued to board it. 

On the northern coast of France, 

The French police had struggled to prevent the migrants from reaching the sea as they charged towards it from the dark sand dunes. Several young men turned back to face the police, wielding long sticks and throwing flares or firecrackers. Meanwhile, two women with a child who were unable to keep up with the group were apprehended by the police on the shoreline. One of the women claimed to be from Iraq and expressed her desperation to reunite with her family in the UK. Once the migrants had boarded the inflatable boat, which they had been dragging across the sand, the police ceased their efforts to intervene. At one point, the boat appeared to be stranded on a sandbar due to the retreating tide, but it later moved further out to sea. We waited as daylight improved and observed that several small rescue boats had been launched from a large French maritime rescue ship stationed off the coast. The rescue boats seemed to circle the now distant inflatable boat for a time. It was only hours later that we learned there were fatalities on board the inflatable boat.
14.2_en:
Along the northern French coast, 

A large number of individuals, desperate to reach the sea, surged towards it from the dark sand dunes. Amidst them, some young men confronted the French authorities, brandishing long sticks and igniting flares or firecrackers. Simultaneously, two women, one carrying a child, were detained by the police on the shoreline. One of the women, hailing from Iraq, pleaded with the officers to be reunited with her family in the UK. With the migrants having embarked on the overcrowded inflatable boat they had dragged across the sand, the police ceased their attempts to interfere. The boat seemed momentarily stranded on a sandbar due to the receding tide, but it eventually resumed its journey towards the open sea. As daylight broke, we observed several small rescue boats being launched from a large French maritime rescue ship anchored offshore. These boats circled the now distant inflatable boat for a while. It was only much later that we were informed of the tragic loss of lives on board the inflatable boat.

15.0_en:
Fulham have reached an agreement with Arsenal to sign midfielder Emile Smith Rowe for an initial £27m with the potential of £7m in add-ons.

Smith Rowe is a club record signing for Fulham and sources say the add-ons are based on Cup and European success for the Cottagers.

The 23-year-old has been left out of Arsenal's past two pre-season matches as the deal was completed.

Smith Rowe is an academy graduate and a popular figure among supporters but has dropped down the pecking order at Arsenal behind Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard and Bukayo Saka.

The midfielder has three England caps, the last of which came in 2022.

Meanwhile, Arsenal have signed Italy defender Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a fee of up to £42m.
15.1_en:
Fulham have agreed to a deal with Arsenal to acquire midfielder Emile Smith Rowe in a transaction worth an initial £27m, with the possibility of an additional £7m in add-ons, contingent on the team's Cup and European competition success.

Smith Rowe's transfer to Fulham makes him the club's record signing, with sources indicating that the add-ons are tied to the team's achievements in Cup and European competitions.

The 23-year-old was absent from Arsenal's past two pre-season matches as the transfer negotiations were finalized.

As an academy graduate and a well-liked figure among supporters, Smith Rowe has seen his playing time dwindle at Arsenal, relegated to a position behind Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka in the team's pecking order.

Smith Rowe has earned three England caps, with his last appearance being in 2022.

In a separate move, Arsenal has signed Italy's Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a fee that could reach up to £42m.
15.2_en:
Arsenal have agreed to transfer midfielder Emile Smith Rowe to Fulham in a deal worth an initial £27m, with the potential for an additional £7m in bonuses dependent on the team's success in cup and European competitions.

The acquisition of Smith Rowe, who is 23 years old, marks Fulham's record signing, with sources indicating that the bonuses are tied to the team's performance in cup and European competitions.

During the finalization of the transfer negotiations, Smith Rowe was absent from Arsenal's last two pre-season matches.

As an academy graduate and a well-liked figure among fans, Smith Rowe has seen his playing time decrease at Arsenal, relegated to a position behind Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka in the team's pecking order.

Smith Rowe has earned three England caps, with his last appearance being in 2022.

In a separate move, Fulham have signed Italy's Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a fee that could reach up to £42m.
15.3_en:
Fulham have secured a record signing in midfielder Emile Smith Rowe, who will join the team from Arsenal in a deal worth an initial £27m, with the possibility of an additional £7m in bonuses, contingent on the team's success in cup and European competitions.

16.0_en:
Man, 92, to go on trial for 1967 rape and murder case

Ryland Headley appeared via video link at Bristol Magistrates' Court on Wednesday

A 92-year-old man will go on trial next year after being charged with the rape and murder of an elderly woman 57 years ago. Louisa Dunne, 75, was found strangled on her living room floor by a neighbour on Brittania Road in Easton, Bristol, on 28 June 1967. Ryland Headley, of Clarence Road, Ipswich, was charged by Avon and Somerset Police on Wednesday, following a further forensic examination of some items. His trial, on 16 June, will take place before a High Court judge and is expected to last up to three weeks.

Louisa Dunne was found dead in her home in 1967

Mr Headley, who was remanded into custody, is accused of the rape and murder of Ms Dunne on dates between June 26 and 29 1967. A plea and trial preparation hearing was fixed for 14 February. No application for bail was made.

Tell us which stories we should cover in Bristol
16.1_en:
A 92-year-old man is set to stand trial next year for a decades-old crime. Ryland Headley, who appeared remotely at Bristol Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, has been charged with the rape and murder of a 75-year-old woman in 1967. 

The victim, Louisa Dunne, was discovered strangled on the living room floor of her home on Brittania Road in Easton, Bristol, on June 28, 1967. Following a re-examination of some items, Avon and Somerset Police charged Headley, who resides on Clarence Road in Ipswich. His trial, scheduled to commence on June 16, will be presided over by a High Court judge and is expected to last up to three weeks.

Ryland Headley was remanded into custody and is accused of raping and murdering Louisa Dunne between June 26 and 29, 1967. A plea and trial preparation hearing has been scheduled for February 14, and no request for bail was made.

17.0_en:
A woman, 38, and two children aged 10 and 13 were taken to hospital

A woman has been charged with attempted murder after a suspected poisoning in Sussex.

Jilumol George, 38, of Hunters Way, Uckfield, was arrested and charged with two counts of attempted murder and two counts of administering poison with intent to endanger life or inflict grievous bodily harm.

Police had attended a property in Hunters Way, Uckfield, on Thursday.

They found a 38-year-old woman and two children, aged 10 and 13, inside.

All three were taken to hospital for treatment but have since been discharged.

She has been remanded in custody to appear before a crown court on 8 March.

Sussex Police Ch Insp Mark Evans said: "This is a fast moving investigation and there will be an increased police presence in the area over the next few days.

"I want to reassure the local community that this is an isolated incident, and we are not looking for anyone else in connection with it."

Follow BBC South East on Facebook, on X, and on Instagram. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
17.1_en:
In Sussex, a 38-year-old woman named Jilumol George was taken into custody and charged with four offenses following a suspected poisoning incident. She is accused of attempting to murder and administering poison with intent to harm grievously two children, aged 10 and 13, and herself. The event transpired at a residence in Hunters Way, Uckfield, on a Thursday. Emergency services arrived at the scene and transported the woman and the two minors to the hospital for treatment, which they have since been discharged from. George remains in custody and is scheduled to appear before a crown court on March 8.

Chief Inspector Mark Evans of Sussex Police stated, "This investigation is progressing rapidly, and the public can expect a heightened police presence in the area for the upcoming days. I aim to alleviate concerns within the community by emphasizing that this is an isolated occurrence, and we are not seeking any further suspects in relation to this incident."

For further information and updates, follow BBC South East on Facebook, X, and Instagram. Please submit story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk. The BBC holds no responsibility for the content of external websites.

18.0_en:
Wales' First Minister Mark Drakeford fought back tears as he made a farewell speech on his last day in office.

While addressing colleagues in the Senedd, the 69-year-old had to pause briefly as he mentioned the death of his wife of 46 years, Clare, saying the past 12 months had been the "hardest and saddest of my life".

Touching on the pandemic, among other things, he said he hoped he led a "way through Covid which made people in Wales feel that they were being kept safe".

He received a standing ovation at the end of his speech and will be succeeded by Vaughan Gething on Wednesday.
18.1_en:
Wales' outgoing First Minister, Mark Drakeford, struggled to hold back tears as he delivered his final address to colleagues in the Senedd on his last day in office.

Pausing momentarily, he reflected on the past year, which had been the most difficult and sorrowful period of his life due to the loss of his wife, Clare, whom he had been married to for 46 years.

During his speech, he touched on various topics, including the pandemic, and expressed his hope that his leadership had provided Wales with a sense of security and protection throughout the challenging time.

As his farewell speech came to a close, he received a well-deserved standing ovation from his colleagues, marking the end of his tenure. He will be succeeded by Vaughan Gething on Wednesday.
18.2_en:

Taking a brief pause, he looked back on the past year, which had been the most trying and heartbreaking period of his life, following the loss of his wife, Clare, whom he had been married to for nearly five decades.

Throughout his farewell speech, Drakeford touched on several key issues, including the pandemic, and expressed his desire that his leadership had provided Wales with a sense of stability and safeguarding throughout the turbulent time.

As his farewell speech came to a close, he received a well-deserved standing ovation from his colleagues, marking the end of his tenure. He will be succeeded by Vaughan Gething on Wednesday.

In his farewell speech, Drakeford addressed several major topics, including the pandemic, and expressed his hope that his leadership had given Wales a sense of security and protection during the tumultuous time.

As Drakeford concluded his speech, his colleagues paid tribute to him with a heartfelt standing ovation, signaling the end of his term. Vaughan Gething will assume the role starting on Wednesday.

In his heartfelt farewell address, Drakeford underscored the pivotal moments that had profoundly impacted Wales' identity, such as the pandemic, and acknowledged the vital role his government had played in offering comfort and continuity during times of uncertainty.

As Drakeford brought his speech to a close, members of the Senedd stood up in a show of respect, marking the end of his term and the impending start of Vaughan Gething's tenure as First Minister, set to commence the following Wednesday.

19.0_en:
An indoor monitoring camera shows the moment a dog unintentionally caused a house fire after chewing on a portable lithium-ion battery power bank.

In the video released by Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, two dogs and a cat can be seen in the living room before a spark started the fire that spread within minutes.

Tulsa Fire Department public information officer Andy Little said the pets escaped through a dog door, and according to local media the family was also evacuated safely.

"Had there not been a dog door, they very well could have passed away," he told CBS affiliate KOTV.
19.1_en:
A surveillance camera installed inside a home captured the moment a dog inadvertently triggered a house fire after gnawing on a portable lithium-ion battery power bank.

The footage, released by the Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, shows three pets - two dogs and a cat - in the living room before a spark ignited the fire, which rapidly spread within a short time frame.

According to Andy Little, a public information officer for the Tulsa Fire Department, the pets managed to escape through a dog door, and, as reported by local media, the family was safely evacuated from the premises.

Little noted that if there hadn't been a dog door in place, the pets could have potentially perished.
19.2_en:

In the video, released by the local fire department, three animals - two dogs and a cat - are seen in the living room before a spark ignited the blaze, which quickly spread.

As stated by Andy Little, a representative of the Tulsa Fire Department, the pets successfully exited the house via a dog door, allowing them to safely evacuate. Local news outlets reported that the family was unharmed.

Little emphasized that the presence of a dog door was crucial, as without it, the pets might not have survived the fire.

Footage captured by a living room security camera showed the rapid spread of the flames, putting two dogs and a cat in grave danger. Miraculously, the homeowners were at home when the fire began and were able to swiftly lead their pets to safety through a dog door, securing their own escape before the smoke became unbearable.

According to Andy Little, a fire department spokesperson, the homeowners had evacuated the premises before the fire reached its peak intensity, thereby guaranteeing their own safety. Little stressed the vital role of the dog door in allowing the pets to flee the toxic smoke, which could have been fatal had they not had a means of escape.

A security camera in the living room recorded the rapid progression of the flames, placing two dogs and a cat in imminent danger. Fortunately, the homeowners were present when the fire ignited and managed to save their pets by quickly guiding them out of the house via a dog door. The homeowners themselves evacuated before the fire reached its most intense stage, ensuring their own safety. According to Andy Little, a fire department spokesperson, the timely use of the dog door was crucial in enabling the pets to escape the hazardous smoke, which could have been lethal had they not had an exit.

20.0_en:
During that update, police said they had analysed the substance used in the attack on Wednesday, and had narrowed it down to two potential very strong alkalis.

It's worth remembering that alkalis are not difficult to come by. They can be found in many common household items from bicarbonate of soda to drain cleaner.

But not all of these substances are harmful to human health - it depends how strong they are.

Weak alkalis are unlikely to cause any harm. In fact they can be consumed - such as baking soda in cakes.

It is products that contain strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide that cause damage , these are most commonly used in strong household cleaners and the paper industry.

A common misconception is that is it only acids which are corrosive, but strong alkalis like this can also cause serious damage to humans.

Depending on how long you are exposed, the type of exposure (ingestion or skin contact) and the dose it can cause severe burns to tissue, accumulation of fluid in the lungs and blindness.
20.1_en:
During that update, police stated they had examined the substance used in the attack on Wednesday and had identified it as likely being one of two extremely potent alkalis. 

It's essential to note that alkalis are relatively easy to obtain, as they can be found in numerous everyday household items, ranging from baking soda to drain cleaners. 

However, not all these substances pose a threat to human health; their potential harm depends on their strength. 

Mild alkalis, for instance, are generally harmless and can even be safely consumed in certain contexts, such as baking soda in baked goods.

On the other hand, products containing strong alkalis, such as sodium hydroxide, are more likely to cause damage. These substances are commonly used in strong household cleaners and the paper industry.

A common misconception is that only acids are corrosive, but strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide can also inflict serious harm on humans.

The extent of the damage caused by these substances depends on factors such as the duration of exposure, the type of exposure (ingestion or skin contact), and the dose. Prolonged or severe exposure can result in severe burns to tissues, fluid accumulation in the lungs, and even blindness.

Two potent alkaline compounds are suspected to be behind a recent occurrence, according to officials. It's crucial to note that these substances, which can be found in everyday items such as baking soda and drain cleaners, come in varying degrees of danger.

Weaker alkaline substances, like those present in baking soda, are generally harmless and can be safely ingested or used under certain conditions. In contrast, stronger alkalines, like sodium hydroxide, pose greater risks due to their extensive usage in powerful household cleaners and the manufacturing sector.

Contrary to popular belief, strong alkalines, such as sodium hydroxide, can be just as damaging to humans as acids.

The level of harm inflicted by these substances depends on several factors, including the duration and manner of exposure (ingestion or skin contact), as well as the quantity. Prolonged or intense exposure can lead to serious tissue damage, lung edema, and even blindness.

Substances like sodium hydroxide, commonly found in strong household cleaning products and industrial settings, are often misjudged as being less hazardous than acids. However, their hazardous properties are comparable to those of acids, highlighting a common misconception.

The extent of harm caused by these substances depends on several critical factors, including the duration and form of exposure (ingestion or skin contact) and the quantity used. Prolonged or excessive exposure can lead to severe tissue damage, respiratory issues, and potentially even vision loss.

21.0_en:
So, that's it - Donald Trump has testified in his second civil defamation trial brought by writer E Jean Carroll. We're now wrapping up our live coverage.

His brief testimony lasted just four minutes, which took us all a bit by surprise here in the newsroom.

The short time on the stand was because Judge Lewis Kaplan had given Trump a very limited scope of what he could talk about. A separate trial last year found Trump sexually assaulted Carroll, so it meant he couldn't repeat his denials and had to stick to what was relevant in the case.

Court returns tomorrow for closing arguments and the jury to be sent off for deliberations. For a write-up of today, that's here.
21.1_en:
Donald Trump has completed his testimony in his second civil defamation trial, brought by writer E Jean Carroll, marking the end of our live coverage. 

His brief appearance on the stand lasted just four minutes, catching us off guard in the newsroom.

The brevity of his testimony was due to the restrictions imposed by Judge Lewis Kaplan, who limited the scope of Trump's discussion. As a result of a previous trial, where Trump was found liable for sexually assaulting Carroll, he was barred from repeating his denials and was only allowed to address relevant points in the case.

The court will reconvene tomorrow for closing arguments, after which the jury will begin deliberations. For a summary of today's events, please refer to our write-up available here.

This was similar to a previous trial where Trump was instructed to focus on the most crucial matters after being prohibited from repeating his denials regarding an alleged assault on Carroll.

The court will reconvene tomorrow with closing arguments, after which the jury will begin their deliberations. For a detailed account of today's proceedings, please refer to our comprehensive written report available here.

22.0_en:
Ex-Met Police officer David Carrick appeared in court after being charged with eight sexual offences

A former Met Police officer has appeared in court charged with eight sex offences against a woman and a girl. David Carrick, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, has been accused of two counts of rape, one count of sexual assault and a count of coercive and controlling behaviour against a woman between 2014 and 2019 in Stevenage. He has also been charged with five counts of indecent assault on a girl under 14 in Salisbury, Wiltshire, between 1989 and 1990, when he was a teenager. The 49-year-old appeared via videolink at Westminster Magistrates' Court, where he was remanded in custody to appear at the Old Bailey in London on 14 November.

Mr Carrick, who was dressed in a grey tracksuit, spoke only to confirm his name and age. No pleas were entered. He has previously served with the Parliamentary and Diplomatic Protection Command within the Metropolitan Police.

Do you have a story suggestion for Beds, Herts & Bucks?

Carrick is under investigation for eight criminal charges, which include two rapes and a sexual assault of a woman in Stevenage from 2014 to 2019, and five counts of indecent assault against a minor girl in Salisbury, Wiltshire, during the late 1980s. At the court session, no pleas were entered, and Carrick was subsequently detained. His upcoming trial is scheduled for November 14th at the Old Bailey. It is worth mentioning that Carrick's previous role in the Metropolitan Police's Parliamentary and Diplomatic Protection Command might generate local attention due to his connection to the police force.

23.0_en:
King will be disappointed he can't be out meeting people - former adviser

More now from the King's former communications secretary JulianPayne, who said the Palace will have prepared for a situation like this. The Palace is "nothing if not excellent at preparation", he said. "So whilst this is an unwelcome surprise, I don't think that it will require a significant new change to some of these structures that are in place." Payne, who worked for the King and Camilla for five years until 2021, also told the BBC's Newshour programme he's sure the King will be keen to return to his public engagements once and if it is deemed prudent. "He will be deeply frustrated that he can't go out and meet people. "He really, really enjoys that. He comes back absolutely fired up from all of the conversations."
23.1_en: The King's former communications secretary, Julian Payne, believes the Palace is well-equipped to handle the current situation. According to Payne, who served under the King and Camilla for five years until 2021, the Palace is known for its meticulous preparation. Although the current circumstances are unwelcome, Payne doesn't think it will necessitate significant changes to existing structures. He is confident that the King will be eager to resume his public engagements once deemed safe, citing the King's enthusiasm for interacting with people. Payne notes that the King derives great satisfaction from meeting people, often returning from such interactions feeling invigorated and motivated.

24.0_en:
It was another busy morning on this week's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg. We're closing our coverage now, but before we go here's a recap from today's show.

We heard from Defence Minister Grant Shapps, who acknowledged that families have been let down over decades by the infected blood scandal, though he wouldn't be drawn on the amount of compensation due.

On Ukraine he said the west "took its eye off the ball" and he doesn't want a direct conflict with Russia.

Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting outlined plans to cut NHS waiting lists and said a future Labour government would ensure victims of the infected blood scandal are compensated.

We also had an interview with Leonid Volkov, former aide to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. He says he doesn't think a Putin victory is possible and that the Russian president is "bluffing".

Our panel today were journalist Piers Morgan, climate campaigner Mikaela Loach and former Tory donor and businessman David Ross.

This page was written by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong and Lou Newton, and edited by me.

See you next week.
• You can continue reading here: Infected blood victims have waited too long, says Grant Shapps
24.1_en:
Today's edition of Laura Kuenssberg's Sunday programme has come to a close, but let's take a moment to review the key points from this morning's show.

Defence Minister Grant Shapps acknowledged the long-standing pain suffered by families affected by the infected blood scandal, yet he declined to specify the amount of compensation that will be provided.

Regarding Ukraine, Mr. Shapps stated that the west made a critical mistake by diverting its attention from the situation, and he emphasized the need to avoid direct conflict with Russia.

Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting outlined his party's plan to reduce NHS waiting lists and pledged that a future Labour government would ensure that victims of the infected blood scandal receive fair compensation.

We also had the opportunity to speak with Leonid Volkov, former aide to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. He expressed his confidence that a Putin victory is unlikely and believes the Russian president is resorting to bluffing tactics.

Our panel today consisted of journalist Piers Morgan, climate campaigner Mikaela Loach, and businessman David Ross, who provided valuable insights and perspectives on the issues at hand.

This page was written by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton, with editing oversight by myself.

We were joined by Leonid Volkov, a former aide to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. He expressed his belief that Putin's victory is uncertain and that the Russian president is employing bluffing tactics.

This article was penned by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton, with editing supervision from me.

Defence Minister Grant Shapps acknowledged the difficulties faced by families affected by the contaminated blood scandal but refused to reveal the exact compensation amount they will receive.

In his speech, Mr. Shapps criticized the Western world for prioritizing other matters over Ukraine and underscored the significance of avoiding a direct confrontation with Russia.

Labour's Shadow Health Secretary, Wes Streeting, presented his party's strategy to reduce NHS waiting lists and guaranteed that a potential Labour government would ensure fair compensation for those impacted by the contaminated blood scandal.

Leonid Volkov, a former advisor to the late Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny, expressed doubt about Putin's expected victory and suggested that Russian President Putin is using deceitful tactics to achieve his goals.

This article was written by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton, with editorial oversight.

UK Defense Minister Grant Shapps expressed regret for the difficulties caused by the contaminated blood scandal, but declined to offer any assurance of reparations or compensation.

In contrast, Labour's Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting outlined his party's strategy for managing NHS waiting lists, ensuring that a Labour government would secure fair compensation for those affected by the tainted blood scandal.

In the meantime, Leonid Volkov, an ex-advisor to Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, cast doubt on the authenticity of Putin's election triumph and insinuated that the Russian President was employing unusual tactics to accomplish his goals.

25.0_en:
Bank needs to see more evidence before cutting rates, says governor

Reporting from the Bank of England

The governor of the Bank of England says it needs to "see more evidence" that price rises have slowed further before cutting interest rates. Andrew Bailey said he was "optimistic that things are moving in the right direction" as rates were held at a 16-year high of 5.25% for the sixth time in a row. Bailey says the Bank expects inflation, which measures the rate prices rise at, will fall "close" to its 2% target in the next couple of months. It paves the way for a first interest cut to be made in the summer, possibly as early as June if inflation falls as predicted. Bailey said there had been "encouraging news" on inflation, which official figures last month showed had fallen further to 3.2%. "We need to see more evidence that inflation will stay low before we can cut interest rates," he said.
25.1_en: The governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, stated that the bank requires additional proof that the pace of price increases has decelerated significantly before reducing interest rates. In a report from the Bank of England, Bailey expressed optimism about the current trend, as the interest rate remained unchanged at a 16-year high of 5.25% for the sixth consecutive month. The Bank anticipates that inflation, which indicates the speed at which prices rise, will approach its 2% target in the upcoming months. This forecast opens the possibility for the first rate reduction to occur during the summer, potentially as soon as June, if inflation declines as anticipated. Bailey acknowledged the recent positive developments regarding inflation, which the latest official statistics indicated had decreased to 3.2%. However, he emphasized that the bank needs to observe more compelling evidence that inflation will remain subdued before making any rate reductions.
25.2_en: Andrew Bailey, the head of the Bank of England, expressed the need for further evidence that the rate of price increases is markedly slowing down before the bank considers lowering interest rates. The interest rate has remained unchanged at 5.25% for six consecutive months, a figure last seen in 2007, and is forecasted to align with the Bank's objective of 2% inflation eventually, paving the way for possible interest rate cuts by June. Bailey acknowledged that inflation has fallen to 3.2%, yet emphasized that indisputable proof of price stability is indispensable before considering lowering interest rates.

26.0_en:
France captain Kylian Mbappe was named on the bench for Friday's Euro 2024 Group D game against the Netherlands.

The 25-year-old striker was forced off during Monday's 1-0 victory over Austria after breaking his nose.

He took part in training on Thursday wearing a mask featuring the French tricolor, and boss Didier Deschamps said "everything was moving in the right direction" for him to be available to face the Dutch.

But Mbappe was instead among the substitutes, with Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram named in the attack.

Mbappe emerged for the warm-up in a single colour mask, instead of the one he wore in training, because of Uefa regulations.

On Thursday, Griezmann said his team-mate's absence would be a blow to the team.

“The whole team has to adapt," he said. "He’s one of the best players in the world, whether you have him or not makes a huge difference.

“You always have to adapt in football. We'll have to adapt for everyone, and that has to be our strength too.”
26.1_en:
Kylian Mbappe, the 25-year-old French soccer team captain and striker, was left out of the starting lineup for the Euro 2024 Group D match against the Netherlands on Friday. This decision came after Mbappe suffered a broken nose during Monday's 1-0 win over Austria and was subsequently sidelined.

Although Mbappe participated in training on Thursday while wearing a mask with the French tricolor colors, Didier Deschamps, the team's manager, announced that Mbappe would be among the substitutes. In his place, Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram were selected to start in the attack.

During the warm-up, Mbappe donned a single-color mask instead of the one he wore during training due to Uefa regulations. Griezmann, Mbappe's teammate, expressed his disappointment at Mbappe's absence and acknowledged the impact his teammate has on the team.

"The whole team must adapt," Griezmann stated. "He's one of the best players in the world, and having him or not makes a significant difference. We must always adapt in football. We'll have to adapt for everyone, and that should also be our strength."

Although Mbappe participated in training on Thursday while wearing a mask bearing the French tricolor colors, team manager Didier Deschamps announced that Mbappe would be among the substitutes. In his place, Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram were chosen to start in the attack.

Before the match, Mbappe switched to a single-color mask from the one he wore during training due to Uefa regulations. Griezmann, Mbappe's teammate, expressed his disappointment at Mbappe's absence and acknowledged the significant impact his teammate has on the team.

Griezmann stated, "The whole team must adapt. He's one of the best players in the world, and his presence or absence makes a significant difference. We must always adapt in football. We'll have to adapt for everyone, and that should also be our strength."
